data.title: What Happened in December 1931
data.meta_description: What happened in December 1931. Browse historical events, famous birthdays and notable deaths from Dec 1931 or search by date, day or keyword.
data.text:
Historical Events

Ottawa branch of Royal Mint begins operation as Royal Canadian Mint

Alka Seltzer goes on sale

CFL Grey Cup, Molson Stadium, Montreal: Montreal AAA Winged Wheelers shutout Regina Roughriders, 22-0 for their first title

Bradman Scores 219

After scoring 226 in 1st Test in Brisbane, Don Bradman belts 219 for NSW against the visiting South Africa at the Sydney Cricket Ground

Coaxial cable patented

Baseball cuts squad from 25 to 23 players & NL continues to prohibit uniform numbers

Dec 9 Benn W Levy's "Springtime for Henry" premieres in NYC

Dec 9 Japanese army attacks Chinese province of Jehol

Dec 9 Spain becomes a republic

Nobel to 1st American Woman Nobel

Jane Addams named co-recipient of Nobel Peace Prize; 1st American woman Nobel laureate [1]

Azaña Spanish PM

Manuel Azaña becomes Prime Minister of Spain with Niceto Zamora as President

Japan leaves the Gold Standard

Dec 11 Statute of Westminster gives complete legislative independence to Canada, Australia, New Zealand, South Africa, Ireland (Free State), and Newfoundland (not then part of Canada)

Japanese government of Imukai forms

National Football League Championship: Green Bay Packers (12-2-0) win 3rd straight first past the post title

1st assembly of Anton Musserts NSB in Utrecht

German SPD begins Iron Front against fascism

Indian Statistical Institute

First meeting of the Indian Statistical Institute organized by Prasanta Chandra Mahalanobis in Calcutta

United Australia Party led by Joseph Lyons defeats the incumbent first-term Australian Labor Party led by Prime Minister James Scullin in a federal election

Diego Rivera Retrospective

Retrospective show of Mexican artist Diego Rivera opens at The Museum of Modern Art in New York

Albert Lonergan scores 137 SA v Qld at Adelaide before 5,697

Dec 25 Fleetwood-Smith takes 5-69 Victoria v Tas at Hobart

Dec 25 NY's Metropolitan Opera broadcasts an entire opera over radio

"Of Thee I Sing"

George Gershwin, Ira Gershwin, George S. Kaufman and Morrie Ryskind's musical political satire "Of Thee I Sing" opens at the Music Box Theatre, NYC; runs for 441 performances, and becomes first musical to win Pulitzer Prize for Drama

Lin-Sen Succeeds Chiang Kai-shek

Lin-Sen succeeds Chiang Kai-shek as President of Nanjing-China

Identification of heavy water publicly announced, HC Urey

Dec 29 Victoria score 7 for 435 in second innings to beat NSW

City of Paris accepts donation of the writings gathered by feminist publisher Marguerite Durand and establishes a library (Bibliothèque Marguerite Durand) for the collection

Famous Birthdays

Jim Nesbitt, American country music singer, born in Bishopville, South Carolina (d. 2007)

Dec 1 Jimmy Lyons, American jazz saxophonist and composer (Cecil Taylor), born in Jersey City, New Jersey (d. 1986)

Edwin Meese

American author and 75th United States Attorney General (1985-88), born in Oakland, California

Dec 2 Masaaki Hatsumi, Japanese founder and head of the Bujinkan Organization, born in Noda, Chiba, Japan

Dec 2 Wynton Kelly, American jazz pianist (Dizzy Gillespie; Miles Davis), born in Brooklyn, New York (d. 1971)

Ellen Blazer [Esther Clara Blazer], Dutch TV director (Sonja), born in Rotterdam, Netherlands (d. 2013)

Dec 3 Franz Josef Degenhardt, German poet and author, born in Schwelm, Westphalia, Germany (d. 2011)

Dec 3 [Mary] Jaye P. Morgan, American pop singer ("All I Want From You"), game show panelist (Gong Show), born in Mancos, Colorado

Alex Delvecchio, Canadian ice hockey forward, coach, and executive (Stanley Cup 1952, 54-55, Detroit Red Wings 1,549 games, 1,281 points), born in Fort William, Ontario

Dec 4 Roy Kidd, American College Football HOF coach (Eastern Kentucky University 1964-2002, record 314–124–8), born in Corbin, Kentucky (d. 2023)

Dec 4 Wally George, American conservative TV commentator, born in Oakland, California (d. 2003)

Zeki Müren, Turkish actor, singer, and composer (Game of Silence), born in Bursa, Turkey (d. 1996)

Bobby Osborne, American bluegrass mandolin player (The Osborne Brothers - "Rocky Top"), born in Thousandsticks, Kentucky (d. 2023)

Rudolf Komorous, Czech-born Canadian composer, born in Prague, Czechoslovakia

Ladislav Smoljak, Czech director, actor and screenwriter (An Uncertain Season), born in Prague, Czechoslovakia (d. 2010)

Dec 9 William Reynolds, American actor (The Gallant Men, All That Heaven Allows), born in Los Angeles, California

Anne Heywood [Violet Pretty], British actress (The Fox) and "Miss Great Britain (1950), born in Handsworth, Birmingham, England

Dec 11 Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh, Indian leader of the Rajneesh movement, born in Kuchwada Village, Raisen district, Bhopal State, British India (d. 1990)

Rita Moreno

Puerto Rican singer, dancer and actress (West Side Story), born in Humacao, Puerto Rico

Ali-Akbar Sa'idi Sirjani, Iranian writer and journalist, born in Sirjan, Kerman (d. 1994)

Jaun Elia, Pakistani scholar, poet and philosopher, born in Amroha, Uttar Pradesh, British India (d. 2002)

Evald Schorm, Czech film director (Courage for Every Day), born in Prague, Czechoslovakia (d. 1988)

Karl Denver [Angus McKenzie], Scottish pop singer ("Never Say Goodbye"; "Wimoweh"), born in Springburn, Glasgow, Scotland (d. 1998)

Dec 16 Kenneth Gilbert, Canadian harpsichordist, organist, musicologist, and educator, born in Montreal, Quebec (d. 2020)

Dec 16 Lars Björn, Swedish International Ice Hockey Fed HOF defenceman (217 caps; World C'ship gold 1953, 57; Olympic bronze 1952; Djurgårdens IF), born in Stockholm, Sweden (d. 2024)

Dec 16 Shelby Singleton, American record label owner and producer (Smash Records, Mercury Records), born in Waskom, Texas (d. 2009)

Tom Brookshier

American football defensive end (Philadelphia Eagles) and broadcaster (CBS), born in Roswell, New Mexico

Dave Madden, Canadian-born American actor (Charlotte's Web, Alice, The Partridge Family), born in Sarnia, Ontario (d. 2014)

Dec 17 Yvonne Keuls [Bamberg], Dutch writer (Jan Rap & Co)

Alison Plowden, English historian (d. 2007)

Dec 18 Allen Klein, American rock and roll business manager - ABKCO (Sam Cooke; Rolling Stones, Beatles), born in Newark, New Jersey (d. 2009)

Dec 18 André S. Labarthe, French actor, film producer and director (Vivre sa vie, Cinéastes de notre temps), born in Oloron-Sainte-Marie, France (d. 2018)

Dec 18 Gene Shue, American NBA basketball guard, 1954-64, 5X All-Star (New York Knicks, Fort Wayne/Detroit Pistons, and 2 other teams), and NBA coach, 1966-89, 2X Coach of the Year (Baltimore/Washington Bullets, Philadelphia 76ers, and 2 other teams), born in Baltimore, Maryland (d. 2022)

Dec 18 Gunnel Lindblom, Swedish actress (Hunger, Virgin Spring), born in Gothenburg, Sweden (d. 2021)

Dec 18 Noel McGregor, New Zealand cricket batsman (25 Tests, 1 x 100; Otago CA), born in Dunedin, New Zealand (d. 2007)

Dec 18 Norm Provan, Australian rugby league second rower (14 Tests; St. George RLFC NSWRL Premiers 1956-66; 13th RL "Immortal") and coach (St. George, Parramatta, Cronulla), born in Urana, Australia (d. 2021)

Mary Ellen "Mala" Powers, American actress (Cyrano de Bergerac, The Wild Wild West), born in San Francisco, California (d. 2007)

Caroline Kaart (neé Raitt), Scottish-Dutch alto singer, TV and radio presenter, born in Blackness, Scotland (d. 2020)

Dec 21 David Baker, American jazz trombonist and cellist, jazz and classical composer (Reflections), and educator (Indiana University), born in Indianapolis, Indiana (d. 2016)

Ronnie Schell, American comedian (Gomer Pyle, Good Morning World), born in Richmond, California

(Erapheael) “Ray” Bryant, American jazz pianist, composer and arranger ("Madison Time"), born in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania (d. 2011)

Dec 24 Jill Bennett, British actress (Lady Jane, Concrete Jungle), born in Penang, Straits Settlements (d. 1990)

Dec 24 Mauricio Kagel, Argentine-German composer, born in Buenos Aires, Germany (d. 2008)

Lefty Driesell, American Basketball HOF coach (first to win 100+ games at 4 different NCAA Div I schools: Davidson College, Uni of Maryland, James Madison, Georgia State), born in Norfolk, Virginia (d. 2024)

Dec 25 Uzo Egonu, painter/print maker

Thomas Eden Binkley, American lutenist and early music scholar, born in Cleveland, Ohio (d. 1995)

(Winfield) Scotty Moore, American guitarist (Elvis Presley; Roy Orbison), born in Gadsden, Tennessee (d. 2016)

Dec 27 Lê Khả Phiêu, Vietnamese leader, General Secretary (1997-2001), born in Thanh Hoa province, Vietnam (d. 2020)

Georg "Org" Marais, South African economist/underminister of Finance

Dec 28 Guy Debord, situationist

Dec 28 John de Mol, Dutch pop vocalist, songwriter, and producer, born in The Hauge, Netherlands (d. 2013)

Dec 28 Martin Milner, American actor (Route 66", "Adam 12"), born in Detroit, Michigan (d. 2015)

Jan Konopásek, Czech-American jazz baritone saxophonist, composer, arranger, and educator, born in Prague, Czechoslovakia (d. 2020)

Dec 29 Prince Gu of Korea, Korean royalty, born in Tokyo Prefecture, Japan (d. 2005)

Charles A Bassett II, American US Air Force Captain, and NASA astronaut, born in Dayton, Ohio (d. 1966)

Dec 30 Ike Skelton, US Congressman (Democrat: 1977-2011), born in Lexington, Missouri (d. 2013)

Dec 30 Richard Christ, writer

Dec 30 Skeeter Davis [Mary Penick], American country-pop singer-songwriter ("(I Can't Help You) I'm Falling Too"; "Set Him Free"; "The End Of The World"), born in Dry Ridge, Kentucky (d. 2004)

Bob Shaw, Northern Irish sci-fi author (Light of Other Days, The Ragged Astronauts), born in Belfast, Northern Ireland (d. 1996)

Dec 31 Gil Mellé, American jazz saxophonist and composer, born in New York City (d. 2004)

Famous Weddings

Clara Bow

Silent film actress Clara Bow (26) weds actor and politician Rex Bell (28) in Las Vegas

Joseph Goebbels

Propagandist Joseph Goebbels (34) weds Magda Ritschel (30) at Günther Quandt's farm in Mecklenburg, Germany

Reinhard Heydrich

SS-Sturmbannfuhrer Reinhard Heydrich marries Lina von Osten

Famous Deaths

Vincent d'Indy

French composer (Symphony on a French Mountain Air), and teacher, dies at 80

Vachel Lindsay, American poet (b. 1879)

Max Elskamp, Belgian author and poet (Six Chansons), dies at 69

Gustave le Bon, French psychologist (b. 1840)

Gustave J Waffelaert, Flemish theologist and bishop of Bruges, dies at 82

Legs Diamond

American gangster and bootlegger during the Prohibition era, shot dead and murdered at 34

(Frederick) Tyrone Power Sr., British-American stage and screen actor (The Big Trial; The Test of Donald Norton), dies of a heart attack at 62

Dec 23 Wilson Bentley, American scientist (b. 1865)

Melvil Dewey, American librarian and educator (created Dewey Decimal System for libraries), dies at 80

Peter C. Lutkin, American organist, composer (The Lord Bless You and Keep You), choral conductor, and educator (Northwestern University, 1891-1931)dies of a heart attack at 73

Dec 27 Walter Courvoisier, Swiss composer, dies at 76
